p: Chitin plays an important role in defining the cell wall nanomechanical properties [ 25, 27, 69], and β-1,3 D-glucan is critical in maintaining cell shape, mechanical rigidity and resistance to osmotic pressure [ 4, 70]. Exposure to CNB oil produced osmotically fragile, swollen cells with an uneven chitin distribution and increased elasticity, consistent with prior studies [ 25, 27, 52, 59]. The elasticity values reported in this study are high in comparison, reflecting cross linking from fixation [ 71]. Inhibition of β-1,3- d-glucan synthase by cinnamaldehyde in S. cerevisiae or by caspofungin in C. albicans results in reduced cell wall β-1,3-glucan [ 22] and increased cell wall chitin content, respectively [ 25]. Furthermore, mutants defective in chitin and β-glucan cross linking ( chr1chr2Δ) have cell wall elasticity that varies with architecture and composition [ 60].
